body: iirc the plan of record is to make pygments a normal dependency of pytest, the syntax coloring right now is considered experimental

@asottile is correct: it is experimental at the moment and we're not 100% sure we will go with pygments just yet, that's why also there's no option to configure styles.

Because it is uncertain, I would not like to add an extra just now because extras can be considered part of the public API.

With pytest 7 out it seems that Pygments-based coloring is now less of an experimental feature â€“ would it perhaps make sense to consider adding it to the list of regular requirements (or as an extra if the opt-in route is preferred)?

issue.title: (ðŸ“š) document pygments

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

issue.body:
when pygments is installed, pytest will color diffs in the output. this should be documented, or provided as an extra

i spent a while trying to figure out why pytest was acting different in different projects

body:
It has been some years now and I we don't have plans to move away from `pygments` any time soon.

I think the safest approach is to add it as an `extra` dependency (`color`?). I would avoid making it a normal dependency for now, [because `pygments` itself uses `pytest`](https://github.com/pygments/pygments/blob/edef94d66c2d70f05a86ac6098a69ab253b8d946/tox.ini#L9).

It would be great if anyone could contribute a PR with that. ðŸ‘

> I would avoid making it a normal dependency for now, [because `pygments` itself uses `pytest`](https://github.com/pygments/pygments/blob/edef94d66c2d70f05a86ac6098a69ab253b8d946/tox.ini#L9).

Is that really as much as a problem as it used to be in previous years, and if so, can we do something about that?

For what it's worth, we already are in the same situation for [exceptiongroup](https://github.com/agronholm/exceptiongroup/blob/main/tests/conftest.py), [packaging](https://github.com/pypa/packaging/blob/main/tests/test_metadata.py) and (maybe to a lesser extent, as under our control) [iniconfig](https://github.com/pytest-dev/iniconfig/blob/main/testing/conftest.py) and [pluggy](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pluggy/blob/main/testing/conftest.py). We also were in the same situation [with attrs](https://github.com/python-attrs/attrs/blob/19.2.0/tests/test_version.py), and from what I can see in #10669 this never was an argument (at least when removing it).

Oh, and as for why it IMHO *shouldn't* be an optional dependency:

- Just more moving parts. Our testsuite breaks without `pygments` installed, so if we accidentally do a change that makes Pygments non-optional, we would never notice.
- Way less discoverability. Even if documented, most people will just `pip install pytest` and not know they're missing out on nicer output.
- Convenience. I test a lot of things in throw-away virtualenvs (also for reproducing pytest bugs and whatnot), and I usually don't think about also installing `pygments` even if I know that pytest would use it if present.

Thanks @The-Compiler, good points about this already being a problem for `exceptiongroup` and `packaging`, I guess this is not much of a problem in practice then.

That said then I'm OK with just adding `pygments` as a normal dependency.

issue.title: Make pygments mandatory and fix string highlighting

labels.name: bot:chronographer:provided
labels.description: (automation) changelog entry is part of PR

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

body: Opened #13189 to turn it into a regular dependency.

Personally I have projects which want minimal dependencies so I appreciate that pygments is optional. But I understand that the way it's currently done is not ideal, so I support making it a required dependency.

Hopefully if Python packaging gains the ability to have "default extras" we could switch to that - add a `color` extra, make it a default but allow people who really want to turn it off. Quick search shows that there is now a draft PEP for this [PEP 771 â€“ Default Extras for Python Software Packages](https://peps.python.org/pep-0771/) so there is hope.

> Personally I have projects which want minimal dependencies

I can see wanting to have minimal direct dependencies, and I can see wanting to have minimal runtime dependencies. I think for a transitive dependency that's also development-only, it might be less of an issue?

> Hopefully if Python packaging gains the ability to have "default extras" we could switch to that

That would be cool! From looking at https://github.com/python/peps/pull/4198 that's only some 2-3 weeks old, but it would definitely make this kind of thing easier!
